ArchaeologicalElement.name: Bone Associated Insitu Materials
ArchaeologicalElement.description: A material associated with a feature cluster

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_in_situ_material
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed in situ

lookup.term: {hearthmaterial} Hearthstones, baked sediment or charcoal
{mussel} Mussel shell or shell fragment
{eggshell} Emu, Genyornis or other eggshell
{stoneart} Chipped, unmodified or ground stone
{otherwork} Other worked or transported material
{all}
{good} Majority of shell is highly fragmented
{moderate} Mixture of fragmented and near whole shell
{poor} Majority of shell is whole or near whole
{other}
{yes}
{no}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Hearth_Material
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {hsclay}
{hscarb}
{hsterm}
{hsother}
{hsindet}
{bakedclay} Thin layer or small lumps of burnt clay, orange in colour when freshly exposed, broken surfaces may be smooth
{bakedsed} Ashy sediment, baked hard
{indet} Baked, ashy or charcoal or organic rich sediment not described above

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Eggshell
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {emu} shell with3-layered structure & orange peel texture; texture only removed if weathering reduces shell thickness to < 0.8mm
{genyo} Shell with single layer, pores appear as short, parallel grooves like pin-pricks
{other} Other eggshell, clearly not emu or Genyornis
{indet} Features unclear due to surface modification or shell & 0.8mm thick and smooth in texture
{yes}
{no}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed

lookup.term: {cs} Chipped stone
{um} Unmodified stone
{ground} Ground stone
{csgs} Chipped and ground stone
{csumgs} Chipped stone, unmodified rock and groundstone
{umgs} Umodified rock and ground stone
{other}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Chipped_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {ru} Retouched/utilised artefact
{co} Core
{deb} Flaking debris, including whole flakes, broken flakes and angular fragments
{hammer} Hammerstone
{indet} Artefact too deeply buried, encursted or covered with sand veneer to determine type
{ruco} Retouched artfact(s) and core(s)
{rudeb} Retouched artefact(s) and debitage
{codeb} Core(s) and debitate
{rucodeb} Retouched artefact(s), core(s) and debitage
{other}
{notch} Retouch that creates one or more concavities along the margin of the tool
{scraper} Flake (or other blank) with one or more margins of retouch
{backed} Flake (or other blank) with one or more margins of retouch
{unifpt} Retouch on one or more margins, which converges to a point in plan view, initiated from a single surface
{bifac} Artefact with bifacial retouch
{otherru} Any other type of retouch or use-wear
{indet} Artefact too deeply buried or surface too encrusted to determine type

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Unmodified_Stone
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {nodule} A large, nodular or rounded cobble (>64 mm)
{slab} A thick, flat piece of rock (>64 mm)
{pebble} Small nodular or rounded piece, < 64 mm maximum dimension, unlikely to be useful for artefact manufacture
{nodslab} Nodule and slab as defined above
{nodpeb} Nodule and pebble as defined above
{slabpeb} Slab and pebble as defined above
{all}
{indet} Rock is too deeply buried or encrusted to determine its size and shape
{other}

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Types_Present
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {millstone} Large, concave to flattish ground surface
{muller} Convex surface with facet from back and forth motion
{mortar} A circular or oval basin
{pestle} A cobble with convex or flattish ground end
{grooved} Single or multiple grooves
{amorph} Poorly defined, or small, discontinuous ground surface, not matching any of the above
{undiag} Fragmentary, not complete enough to distinguish nature of ground surface
{indet} Artefact is too deeply buried or encrusted to determine type
{other}

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Status
property.description: Is the ground material...:

lookup.term: {whole}
{fragment} One or more fragments of a larger artefact or fragments of more than one artefact that do not refit
{refits} Broken fragments can be refitted back together and/or texture, colour, thickness and/or surface modifications suggest that they are part of the same artefact

property.name: OldBone_-_Chipped_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term: {silcfine} Quartz grains less than 0.25 mm
{silcmed} Quartz grains 0.25 – 0.5 mm
{silccoarse} Quartz grains greater than 0.5mm
{silcmicroxtal} Naked eye cannot identify grains in the matrix
{qtzite} Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour
{qtz} A clear, white, milky white or rose coloured mineral
{other} For example, carbonate, chalcedony
{unident}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Unmodified_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term: {silcfine} Quartz grains less than 0.25 mm
{silcmed} Quartz grains 0.25 – 0.5 mm
{silccoarse} Quartz grains greater than 0.5mm
{silcmicroxtal} Naked eye cannot identify grains in the matrix
{qtzite} Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour
{qtz} A clear, white, milky white or rose coloured mineral
{ironst} Sedimentary rock containing iron rich minerals
{sandst} A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains
{other} For example, carbonate or raw material not identified (enter into annotations)
{indet} Artefact is too deeply buried to identify raw material

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term: {silcrete} Scattered quartz grains in a dense matrix
{sandst} A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains
{qtzite} Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour
{ironst} A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains
{other} For example, carbonate or raw material not identified (enter into annotations)
{indet} Too deeply buried to determine raw material type

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Other_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term: {bonemod} Bone with ground or polished surface(s), may be bevelled or pointed at one or both ends
{shellmod} Thick fragment of shell with notches or other evidence of working or use along one or more margins
{eggmod} Eggshell with modified surface, e.g. tooth mark or drill hole
{ochrediss} Flecks or fragments of ochre disseminated through the sediment
{ochrenod} Small nodule of ochre
{ochrefacet} Ochre with facets, indicating use as crayon
{qtzxtal} Unworked quartz crystal
{turbo} Marine gastropod, round shell with white zigzag stripes, up to 4cm long
{other} Any other worked, utilised or transported material not listed above

lookup.term: {bonemod} bone with ground or polished surface(s), may be bevelled or pointed at one or both ends
{shellmod} shell with notches or other evidence of working or use along one or more margins
{ochrediss} flecks or fragments of ochre disseminated through the sediment
{ochrenod} small nodule of ochre
{ochrefacet} ochre with facets, indicating use as crayon
{qtzxtal} unworked quartz crystal
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: Hearth_-_ID_Number
property.description: Feature identification code as marked on tag

property.name: Hearth_-_Brief_description
property.description: A few word description of an ‘other’ type of hearth or hearthstone, e.g. fish hearth, emu eggshell hearth, silcrete hearthstones

lookup.term: {none} No charcoal visible
{diss} Disseminated charcoal: fine particles of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix
{flecks} Small fragments of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix
{indet} Dark particles or flecks visible, but origin indeterminate
{lumps} Large lumps of charcoal within the hearth or its sedimentary matrix
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Proportion_of_material_that_remains_in_situ
property.description: Select the proportion of visible hearth material that remains in situ

lookup.term: {most} The majority of the visible hearth material is in situ
{some} At least some of the hearth is in situ
{surface} No hearth material is embedded in sediment
{recement} The hearth material appears to be in situ, but there is a high likelihood that it is actually cemented in redeposited sediment
{ambiguous} The hearth material appears to be in situ, but it is impossible to say whether it is actually recemented
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Modification_of_heat-retainer_hearths
property.description: Select the degree of post-exposure modification of the heat-retainer hearth:

lookup.term: {none} Hearth structure is largely maintained, hearthstones are in good conditions
{frag} Material highly fragmented
{dispers} Material widely dispersed from in situ or clustered part of hearth
{polish} Hearthstones are smoothed and glossy material
{other} Record in notes

property.name: Hearth_-_Modification_of_non-heat_retainer_hearths
property.description: Select the extent of post-exposure modification to non- heat retainer hearths:

lookup.term: {none} Hearth structure is intact and hearth material is largely unweathered
{weather} Hearth material has started to weather and/or crumble, but the feature remains largely intact
{root} roots or root channels running through the hearth
{incrill} Incipient rill network extending to edge of hearth or cutting back into it
{rill} Well-developed rills are cutting through the hearth
{undercut} Underlying sediment has been removed through erosion
{gul} Feature is bisected by an established gully
{frag} Components of the hearth (eg. baked sediment, emu eggshell) are highly fragmented
{disp} Components of the hearth (eg. baked sediment, emu eggshell) are widely dispersed from in situ or tightly clustered surface material
{fragdisp} Components of the hearth are fragmented and dispersed
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the hearth located?

lookup.term: {platform} Broad, flat platform exposure
{less6Degree} Slightly sloping surface
{6To12Degree} Moderately sloping surface
{greater12Degree} More steeply sloping surface
{shallrill} Within a shallow rill
{rillfloor} In the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)
{rillwall} In the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)
{ridge} On a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area
{ridgerill} Feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow
{shalgulfl} In the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep
{shalgulwal} In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep
{deepgulfl} In the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep
{deepgulwal} In the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep
{residtop} Flat surface on top of a residual
{residside} In the side of a residual
{chanfloor} In the floor of a modern outwash channel
{chanwall} In the wall of a modern outwash channel
{allfan} modern alluvial fan
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the hearth, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term: {redsand} quartz sand of a reddish colour
{brownsand} quartz sands of a brownish colour
{whitesand} sand that is clean (no clay) and white
{othersand} quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)
{clayeysand} quartz sands that contain some clay
{laminarsand} fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate
{redlamsand} red sands preserving fine bedding
{unconsolsand} unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)
{modernaeolian} shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands, coppice sands
{pelletalclay} grey clays made up of clay pellets
{alternat} alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand
{clay-alt} distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{sand-alt} distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{bluelam-alt} mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct ‘blue’ colour
{greenclay} clay of a green colour
{redsoil} soil of a reddish colour
{brownsoil} soil of a brownish colour
{darksoil} soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich
{carbsoft} sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)
{carbnodule} sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)
{carbpavemt} well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement
{carblag} broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag
{finesilt} fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component
{cobblebeach} continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach} relatively continuous bed of rounded gravels and coarse sand
{other}
{Golgol} deeply weathered sands and clays with strong red colour
{ggC} Golgol C horizon: in situ carbonate nodules and sediments cemented together to form distinct pavement (pinkish colour)
{gglag} surface lag made up of broken up, angular pieces of pinkish carbonate nodules, root traces etc derived from the Golgol C
{B} Lower Mungo
{C} Upper Mungo
{D} mega-lake sediments
{E} Arumpo/Zanci
{F} unconsolidated sands reworked lunette sediments
{G} Holocene alluvial fans
{H} modern aeolian
{I} modern alluvium
{indet} stratgraphic unit not yet identified
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the hearth?

lookup.term: {low} On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment
{moderate} Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system
{high} High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment
{extreme} Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the hearth cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term: {foredune} Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed
{backdune} Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland
{crest} Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland
{beach} An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit} Projection from dune into lakebed
{lakebed} Lakebed sediments
{indet} Indeterminate
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Photos
property.description: Take 2 images: 1. landscape/stratigraphic setting (to aid re-location), include horizon and nearby landmarks that will have some longevity 2. the feature itself (to aid identification) – include the critical components of the feature like the in situ portion of a hearth or bone cluster

property.name: Hearth_-_Notes
property.description: Any additional information worth noting that has not been covered by the recording

property.name: Shell_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: Shell_-_ID_Number
property.description: Feature identification code as marked on tag

lookup.term: {dispers} Scattered shells eroding out across > 1metre of exposure, with no associated material, probably non-cultural in origin
{smallclust} A single, discrete cluster containing a handful of mussel shells
{largeclust} A discrete cluster, or multiple discrete clusters, of mussel shell that extend along an horizon for up to 1-2 metres
{extthin} A laterally extensive cluster, exposed along an horizon for more than 2 metres or multiple small clusters of mussel shell that occur in a single
{extthick} A laterally extensive cluster, exposed along an horizon for more than 2 metres or multiple small clusters of mussel shell that occur in a single
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Continuity
property.description: Does it form a continuous blanket or is it patchy?

lookup.term: {continuous} A large or extensive cluster of mussel shells that forms a continuous deposit

{discontin} Multiple clusters of mussel shell that probably formed a continuous deposit prior to erosion, or that represent the first exposure of a deposit that is likely to be continuous (e.g. in same stratigraphic layer)
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Presence_of_charcoal
property.description: Select the type of charcoal visible in the shell midden

lookup.term: {none} No charcoal visible
{diss} Finely disseminated charcoal
{flecks} Flecks of charcoal, dispersed through the sediment or in clusters
{lumps} Large lumps of in situ charcoal present
{indet} Dark staining visible, but origin indeterminate
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Proportion_of_material_that_remains_in_situ
property.description: Select the proportion of visible shell material that remains in situ

lookup.term: {most} The majority of the visible shell material is in situ
{some} At least some of the shells are in in situ
{surface} None of the shells are embedded in sediment
{recement} Some shells appear to be in situ but there is a high likelihood that they have been cemented into redeposited sediment
{ambiguous} The shells appear to be in situ but it is impossible to determine whether they are actually recemented
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Bivalve_preservation
property.description: Select the degree of preservation of the shell material

lookup.term: {good} Majority of shell is whole or near whole, or articulated
{moderate} Mixture of fragmented and near whole shell
{poor} Majority of shell is highly fragmented
{other}
{low} Surface scatter of material is confined to the area of in situ material, or, if only surface material is present, to a discrete, relatively dense, area
{moderate} Some surface material is scattered beyond the in situ or dense area
{high} Surface material extends well beyond in situ or dense material, and is ￼scattered sparsely
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the object located?

lookup.term: {platform} Broad, flat platform exposure
{less6Degree} Slightly sloping surface
{6To12Degree} Moderately sloping surface
{greater12Degree} More steeply sloping surface
{shallrill} Within a shallow rill
{rillfloor} In the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)
{rillwall} In the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)
{ridge} On a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area
{ridgerill} Feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow
{shalgulfl} In the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep
{shalgulwal} In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep
{deepgulfl} In the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep
{deepgulwal} In the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep
{residtop} Flat surface on top of a residual
{residside} In the side of a residual
{chanfloor} In the floor of a modern outwash channel
{chanwall} In the wall of a modern outwash channel
{allfan} modern alluvial fan
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the midden, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term: {redsand} quartz sand of a reddish colour
{brownsand} quartz sands of a brownish colour
{whitesand} sand that is clean (no clay) and white
{othersand} quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)
{clayeysand} quartz sands that contain some clay
{laminarsand} fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate
{redlamsand} red sands preserving fine bedding
{unconsolsand} unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)
{modernaeolian} shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands, coppice sands
{pelletalclay} grey clays made up of clay pellets
{alternat} alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand
{clay-alt} distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{sand-alt} distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{bluelam-alt} mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct ‘blue’ colour
{greenclay} clay of a green colour
{redsoil} soil of a reddish colour
{brownsoil} soil of a brownish colour
{darksoil} soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich
{carbsoft} sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)
{carbnodule} sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)
{carbpavemt} well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement
{carblag} broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag
{finesilt} fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component
{cobblebeach} continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach} relatively continuous bed of rounded gravels and coarse sand
{other}
{Golgol} deeply weathered sands and clays with strong red colour
{ggC} Golgol C horizon: in situ carbonate nodules and sediments cemented together to form distinct pavement (pinkish colour)
{gglag} surface lag made up of broken up, angular pieces of pinkish carbonate nodules, root traces etc derived from the Golgol C
{B} Lower Mungo
{C} Upper Mungo
{D} mega-lake sediments
{E} Arumpo/Zanci
{F} unconsolidated sands reworked lunette sediments
{G} Holocene alluvial fans
{H} modern aeolian
{I} modern alluvium
{indet} stratgraphic unit not yet identified
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the midden?

lookup.term: {low} On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment
{moderate} Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system
{high} High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment
{extreme} Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the object cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term: {foredune} Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed
{backdune} Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland
{crest} Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland
{beach} An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit} Projection from dune into lakebed
{lakebed} Lakebed sediments
{indet} Indeterminate
{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Photos
property.description: Take 2 images: 1. landscape/stratigraphic setting (to aid re-location), include horizon and nearby landmarks that will have some longevity 2. the feature itself (to aid identification) – include the critical components of the feature like the in situ portion of a hearth or bone cluster

{shalgulwal} In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{other}

property.name: Stone_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the object, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term: {redsand} quartz sand of a reddish colour
{brownsand} quartz sands of a brownish colour
{whitesand} sand that is clean (no clay) and white

{clayeysand} quartz sands that contain some clay

{redlamsand} red sands preserving fine bedding
{unconsolsand} unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)
{modernaeolian} shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands, coppice sands
{pelletalclay} grey clays made up of clay pellets
{alternat} alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand
{clay-alt} distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{sand-alt} distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays
{bluelam-alt} mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct ‘blue’ colour
{greenclay} clay of a green colour

{brownsoil} soil of a brownish colour
{darksoil} soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich

{ggC} Golgol C horizon: in situ carbonate nodules and sediments cemented together to form distinct pavement (pinkish colour)

property.name: Stone_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the object?

lookup.term: {low} On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment
{moderate} Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system
{high} High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment
{extreme} Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment
{other}
